Software sales professionals

Diversity talent research

Talent pool insights

Summary of findings

Diversity talent research

  • Adobe is overall in line with competitors' median diversity. There are however some companies that fare better, in particular smaller companies like Twilio, Tableau and Box.
  • There is the need to increase diversity at senior level. This is a known problem and is found across competitors as well, but Adobe's number for senior level diversity are among the worst in the sample: Adobe goes from being the 6th company for share of intermediate female employees to being the 13th for share of senior female employees; and from 4th most ethnically diverse company at intermediate level to 13th at senior level.
  • Adobe’s numbers, both overall and regionally, roughly follow a trend of increasing turnover rate with increasing diversity profile, like its competitros. Adobe however has a higher-than-average turnover rate across all 4 categories of talent considered, in comparison to the other companies in the sample. A gender breakdown of these stats shows that Adobe is struggling more than the other companies with the specific demographic of male ethnically diverse employees, for which Adobe has one of the top 5 highest turnover rates.
  • When looking at the balance between yearly diverse talent hired and diverse talent loss, Adobe has kept overall a positive net balance in the period 2010-2020. The analysis suggests that in the last 1-2 years the balanaced has turned negative, with more ethnically diverse or female talent being lost than it has been hired, however the difference is small. Salesforce is the company that has achieved the highest net gain of ethcnially diverse and female talent in the last years.

Contents

00 Brief

01 Current workforce diversity

02 Hiring

03 Retention

04 Promotion

00 Brief

This presentation looks at patterns in current diversity hires at Adobe and selected competitors. The goal is to assess where Adobe currently stands in terms of diversity in order to set benchmarks and determine what possible directions for improvement the data suggests.

In this analysis, 18 companies have been selected to compare Adobe to: Box, Docusign, Dropbox, episerver, IBM, Microsoft, OKTA, Oracle, Pegasystems, Salesforce, SAP, ServiceNow, Sitecore, Splunk, Tableau, Twilio, Workday, Zendesk. Each company has been analysed in relation to Adobe's three EU regional office locations: France, Germany and United Kingdom. When the regional office is not specified, the data refers to the three locations taken together.

Software sales professionals currently working at Adobe and selected competitors considered in the data sample.

01 Current workforce diversity

In terms of overall diversity, Adobe sits about halfway through the ranking, in the 9th position out of 19 companies. It is estimated that around 43% of the workforce in the sample can be considered diverse either in terms of gender or ethnicity.

In terms of gender diversity, 36% of the Adobe employees in the sample have been classified as female, with Box (50%), Twilio (43%) and Zendesk (41%) being the companies closer to a gender-balanced workforce.

In terms of ethnic diversity, 12% of the Adobe employees in the sample have been classified as ethnically diverse, a ratio comparable to that of bigger companies like Microsoft, Salesforce and SAP. Like for gender diversity, Box ranks as the most ethnically-diverse company, with 16%.

Adobe estimated to be in around the median for both gender and ethnic diversity of its sales workforce

The following chart shows how Adobe's current workforce composition compares with others. Companies in the upper left corner are more diverse, having the an above average share of both female workforce and ethnically diverse workforce. Company bubbles are sized according to workforce size in the sample.

While Adobe can be considered in the median range for overall employee diversity, an analysis of what the numbers look like at different seniority levels shows how Adobe falls behind in keeping a consistent rate of female talent throughout the career ladder.

As seniority level increases, the share of female talent represented in a company's workforce decreases. This pattern is present in almost all of the companies considered, but the drop is particularly stark for Adobe. Overall, Adobe goes from being the 6th company for share of intermediate female employees to being the 13th for share of senior female employees and from the 4th position as most ethnically diverse company at intermediate level to 14th at senior level.

At Adobe, less than 1 every 3 senior employees is female, and less than 1 in 10 is diverse.

The following chart shows how none of the selected companies is close to a 50% female senior workforce, and that the share of female or ethnically diverse employees drops as seniority level rises. The chart can be used to compare rankings between different companies.

02 Hiring

Across all three locations (UK, France and Germany) 15% of Adobe’s new hires have been ethnically diverse talent and 37% female talent (measured over the last 3 years 2018 -2020), placing the company in the bottom half of the ranking. The top performing companies are IBM and Microsoft, and the bottom two being Dropbox and DocuSign.

Diversity of recent hires is not enough to address the current lack of diversity at senior level, as it actually mirrors the same discrepancy seen in the current workforce: 24% of Adobe's new junior hires have been ethnically diverse vs 12% of senior hires, and 46% of Adobe's new junior hires have been female vs only 28% of senior hires.

Company ranking of ethnically diverse and female new hires (as % of total 2018-2020 hires), by seniority level.

Because of the different sample sizes involved, it is useful to read the tooltip associated with each line to correctly interpret the numbers: for example, an 80% diversity over just 3 hires might not be so meaningful.

03 Retention

When looking at the balance between yearly diverse talent hired and diverse talent loss, Adobe has kept overall a positive net balance in the period 2010-2020 and lands in 4th position for overall positive incoming flow of female and ethnically diverse talent. The analysis suggests that in the last 1-2 years the balanaced has turned negative, with more ethnically diverse or female talent being lost than it has been hired, however the difference is small.Salesforce is the company that has achieved the highest net gain of ethcnially diverse and female talent in the last years.

Difference between ethically diverse talent hired and leaving each year, at Adobe and competing companies

The companies appear ranked by their total 2010 – 2020 net balance, so companies with higher incoming balance are first.

Difference between female talent hired and leaving each year, at Adobe and competing companies

The companies appear ranked by their total 2010 – 2020 net balance, so companies with higher incoming balance are first.

Adobe’s numbers, both overall and regionally, roughly follow the overall trend of increasing turnover rate with increasing diversity profile. In comparison to the other companies in the sample, Adobe has a higher-than-average turnover rate across all 4 categories of talent considered, and a gender breakdown of these stats shows that Adobe is struggling most with male ethnically diverse employees, for which Adobe ranks 15/19th for turnover rate.

Turnover rates (2010-2020) at Adobe and competing companies, by workforce diversity

According to the data in the sample, overall Adobe scores well in terms of average tenure* of its workforce and is generally in the first half of the ranking of companies with longest average tenure.. There is no overall clear trend whether female or diverse talent has a longer or shorter average tenure in comparison to the rest of the workforce, as the numbers vary greatly case-by-case.

*average tenure has been calculated in months, looking at people hired by each company in the period 2010-2020

Average tenure (2010-2020) at Adobe and competing companies,by workforce diversity

04 Promotion

Adobe ranks among the top 5 companies with highest promotion rates, across non-ethically diverse talent (male and female) and across ethnically diverse female talent. Perhaps linked to the low retention rate for male ethnically diverse talent, Adobe's promotion rates for male diverse employess also drop, both in comaprison to the rest of Adobe's workfoce and in comparison to competitors' promotion rates for male diverse talent.

Promotion rates (2010-2020) at Adobe and competing companies,by workforce diversity

Unsuprisingly, in almost all of the companies considered top-level* workforce is less diverse than the overall staff. What is interesting is however that at Adobe the diversity gap is particularly large in comparison to its competitors: overall Adobe ranks 3rd least diverse for the difference between diversity of its top-level workforce and its overall workforce, with 68% of top level employees being non ethnically diverse male, against 57% of its overall workforce.

*defined as job titles including these words: 'VP','President','CEO','CIO','CMO','CTO','CFO','Chief','Head','Director','CDO','Lead','Leader'

Share of workforce by diversity of overall and top level employees.
